channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: Dozens of protesters gather for anti-vaccine rally in front of L.A. City Hall, no problems reported
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth, Cindy Carcamo
item.description: About 100 people show to mostly peaceful anti-vaccine rally at Los Angeles City Hall.
item.content:encoded: About 100 people show to mostly peaceful anti-vaccine rally at Los Angeles City Hall.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - SEPTEMBER 18, 2021 - - Dozens of anti-vax protesters rally in front of City Hall in Los Angeles on September 18, 2021. An anti-vaxxer was stabbed and a reporter was sent to the hospital with a head injury at last month's rally at City Hall. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: The Central Valley gives California a recall rarity: a squeaker of a race
item.dc:creator: Maria L. La Ganga, Anita Chabria
item.description: Nearly everywhere you look in California, the special election to kick Gavin Newsom out of the governor's mansion was one blowout after another.
item.content:encoded: Nearly everywhere you look in California, the special election to kick Gavin Newsom out of the governor's mansion was one blowout after another.

media:content.media:description: California Gov. Gavin Newsom, center, receives applause from former farmworkers for the bill expanding heath care coverage for undocumented Californians he signed at Clinica Sierra Vista on Tuesday, July 27, 2021, in Fresno, Calif. Older Californians who are living in the country without permission are newly eligible for state health care coverage under legislation signed by Gov. Newsom Tuesday. (Eric Paul Zamora/The Fresno Bee via AP)

item.title: LAPD officers need COVID vaccine or negative coronavirus test to work overtime at big events

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 06: Chief of the Los Angeles Police Department Michel R Moore presents the United States flag to Maria Martinez, mother of LAPD Officer Valentin Martinez, the agency's first sworn employee to die of complications from the COVID-19. The social distance memory service was held at Forest Lawn Hollywood Hills' Hall of Liberty this morning. Martinez was a 13-year veteran of the department and is presumed to have contacted the virus on duty. He was 45 when he died on July 24, 2020, leaving behind his mother, Maria Martinez, his siblings and his domestic partner, Megan Flynn, who is pregnant with their twins. Los Angeles on Thursday, Aug. 6, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column One: This feminist witch introduced California to Goddess worship
item.dc:creator: Deborah Netburn
item.description: Zsuzsanna Budapest helped bring Goddess religion to the U.S. in the '70s, and was arrested for reading tarot. Now she lives in a retirement community.
item.content:encoded: Zsuzsanna Budapest helped bring Goddess religion to the U.S. in the '70s, and was arrested for reading tarot. Now she lives in a retirement community.

media:content.media:description: Watsonville, California-Aug. 21 2021-Z Susanne Budapest (AKA Z Budapest), is known for originating a Goddess oriented witchcraft called Dianic Wicca with the help of her first coven - the Susan B. Anthony Coven No. 1. Budapest has written 13 books and now lives in Watsonville, California. Photographed outside her home in Watsonville, CA on Aug. 21, 2021, where she grows lavender, grapes, roses, and other plants. (Carolyn Cole / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Fighting fire with fire: How prescribed burns could help save the world's largest trees
item.dc:creator: Hayley Smith
item.description: Officials are banking on a history of prescribed burns in Sequoia National Park to help keep destructive flames from reaching the towering trees of Giant Forest.
item.content:encoded: Officials are banking on a history of prescribed burns in Sequoia National Park to help keep destructive flames from reaching the towering trees of Giant Forest.

media:content.media:description: The General Sherman tree, located in the Giant Forest of Sequoia National Park, has its' base wrapped in fire resistant material to protect it from the KNP Complex fire. Officials are hoping that controlled burns around the giant Sequoia trees will limit damage from the KNP Complex fire.

item.title: Biden administration appeals order to stop expelling migrants under health law
item.dc:creator: Andrea Castillo

item.content:encoded: A federal judge on Thursday gave the government two weeks to halt the use of Title 42 to expel migrants with children who are apprehended at the U.S.-Mexico border.

media:content.media:description: Juana Cruz Funez, 40,(right )from Honduras and her daughter, Itzy Varela Cruz, 8, (center )distraught upon arrival in Reynosa immediately after she and other families were expelled back to Mexico by U.S. Border Patrol.Reynosa, Mexico, across Rio Grande from Texas. Migrant families are deported here each day from the U.S. side. She and others had crossed the Rio Grande on a boat the night before. She arrived at the Plaza de la Republica in Reynosa where hundreds of expelled migrants are squatting. Many fear being kidnapped or robbed in the dangerous border city in the State of Tamaulipas, Mexico.
media:content.media:credit: Liliana Nieto del Rio/For the Ti

item.title: It's flu shot time. Here's how and why to get one

item.content:encoded: It's more important than ever to get a flu shot this year. Here's where to get yours.

item.dc:creator: Alene Tchekmedyian

item.content:encoded: L.A. County Sheriff Alex Villanueva has broad legal authority to crack down on entrenched, gang-like groups of deputies, according to attorneys for the county.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 26: Los Angeles County Sheriff Alex Villanueva discusses organizational change, transparency, accountability and how they relate to the issue of deputy cliques during a press conference at the Hall of Justice Wednesday May 26, 2021. The Sheriff also addressed a damages claim filed by the city of Compton against Los Angeles County today, alleging the sheriff's department has bilked the city out of millions of dollars by falsely reporting the amount of time deputies spend patrolling the city. Sheriff Alex Villanueva dismissed the allegations. "We have about 45 contracts and we measure the minutes, and there's a rate -- we have to get close to 100%, either slightly above or slightly below,'' Villanueva said. "If we're missing that target, I don't think it's going to be the grand conspiracy that the outgoing mayor of Compton wants it to be. "But we'll definitely take the allegation seriously, and we are already doing a thorough audit on it, and we'll take action based on the results of that. Nothing unusual there. But to call it a fraud, that might be a little bit of a stretch.'' Hall of Justice on Wednesday, May 26, 2021 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times).

item.title: California overwhelmingly rejects recall, keeps Newsom as governor
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon, Taryn Luna, Julia Wick

media:content.media:description: SAN LEANDRO, CA - SEPTEMBER 08: Governor Gavin Newsom speaks ahead of Vice President Kamala Harris at a rally against the upcoming California gubernatorial recall election at the IBEW-NECA Joint Apprenticeship Training Center on Wednesday, Sept. 8, 2021 in San Leandro, CA. The recall election, which will be held on September 14, 2021, asks voters to respond two questions: whether Newsom, a Democrat, should be recalled from the Office of Governor, and who would succeed Newsom should he be recalled. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)
